title: 2 Samuel Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Samuel chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Samuel Chapter 13.

questions.question: Who was Amnon in love with according to 2 Samuel 13?
options: Tamar
Bathsheba
Michal
Abigail
questions.correctAnswer: Tamar
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 13:1 states that Amnon the son of David loved Tamar, his sister.

questions.question: What advice did Jonadab give to Amnon to get Tamar to him?
options: Pretend to be sick and ask Tamar to prepare food for him
Invite Tamar to a feast
Send a message asking for a meeting
Hide and wait for Tamar to come
questions.correctAnswer: Pretend to be sick and ask Tamar to prepare food for him
questions.explanation: Jonadab advised Amnon to make himself sick and ask Tamar to prepare food for him (2 Samuel 13:5).

questions.question: What kind of garment was Tamar wearing before Amnon forced her?
options: A garment of divers colours
A simple linen robe
A sackcloth garment
A royal purple robe
questions.correctAnswer: A garment of divers colours
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 13:18 describes Tamar wearing a garment of divers colours, typical for king's daughters who were virgins.

questions.question: How did Tamar express her grief after Amnon forced her?
options: She put ashes on her head and rent her garment
She sang a lament
She fled from the house
She prayed silently
questions.correctAnswer: She put ashes on her head and rent her garment
questions.explanation: According to 2 Samuel 13:19, Tamar put ashes on her head and rent her garment to show her mourning.

questions.question: What was King David's reaction when he heard what Amnon had done to Tamar?
options: He was very wroth
He immediately punished Amnon
He ignored the matter
He sent Tamar away
questions.correctAnswer: He was very wroth
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 13:21 states that king David was very angry when he heard the news.

questions.question: For how long did Absalom remain silent toward Amnon after the incident?
options: Two years
One year
Six months
Three years
questions.correctAnswer: Two years
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 13:23 mentions that two full years passed before Absalom acted on his hatred toward Amnon.

questions.question: Where did Absalom have his sheepshearers, where he invited all the king’s sons?
options: Baalhazor
Geshur
Jerusalem
Hebron
questions.correctAnswer: Baalhazor
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 13:23 says Absalom had sheepshearers in Baalhazor, beside Ephraim, where he invited the king’s sons.

questions.question: What command did Absalom give his servants concerning Amnon at the feast?
options: To kill Amnon when he was drunk
To protect Amnon
To bring Amnon to the king
To send Amnon away
questions.correctAnswer: To kill Amnon when he was drunk
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 13:28 records that Absalom told his servants to kill Amnon when he was merry with wine.

questions.question: What did King David do when he heard the news that Absalom had killed all the king's sons?
options: He tore his garments and lay on the earth
He immediately pursued Absalom
He commanded a feast
He sent a message of peace
questions.correctAnswer: He tore his garments and lay on the earth
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 13:31 states that David tore his clothes and lay on the ground in grief.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Samuel 13, Absalom killed only Amnon and no other sons of the king.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jonadab explained in 2 Samuel 13:32-33 that only Amnon was killed, not all the king’s sons.

questions.question: True or False: Tamar was sent away by Amnon after he forced her.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 13:17 says Amnon commanded his servant to put Tamar out and bolt the door after her.

questions.question: True or False: After the incident, Absalom immediately fled to Geshur without any delay.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Absalom fled after two years and after killing Amnon, as described in 2 Samuel 13:23 and 13:37-38.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Samuel 13:14: 'Howbeit he would not hearken unto her voice: but, being stronger than she, ________.'
options: forced her, and lay with her
listened to her plea
called for help
left the room
questions.correctAnswer: forced her, and lay with her
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 13:14 states that Amnon forced Tamar and lay with her despite her protests.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 2 Samuel 13:20: 'But hold now thy peace, my sister: he is thy brother; ________.'
options: regard not this thing
avenge this wrong
tell the king
speak no more
questions.correctAnswer: regard not this thing
questions.explanation: Absalom told Tamar to hold her peace and not regard what Amnon had done (2 Samuel 13:20).

questions.question: According to 2 Samuel 13, who was Jonadab?
options: Amnon’s friend and a very subtil man
A servant of Absalom
A priest in David’s court
A prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Amnon’s friend and a very subtil man
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 13:3 describes Jonadab as Amnon's friend and a very subtil man.

medium.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Samuel Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 13 teach us about dealing with temptation and trusting God's guidance?
options: Resist temptation by seeking wise counsel and not giving in to lust
Give in to desires if they seem strong and unavoidable
Avoid all relationships to prevent temptation
Ignore the consequences of sinful actions
questions.correctAnswer: Resist temptation by seeking wise counsel and not giving in to lust
questions.explanation: Amnon's lust for Tamar led him to deceit and sin despite warnings (2 Samuel 13:2-5, 11-14). This shows the importance of resisting temptation and seeking godly wisdom.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with forgiveness after being wronged by a family member. Based on 2 Samuel 13, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Harboring hatred can lead to further division and harm
Retaliate immediately to show strength
Ignore the offense completely without addressing it
Seek revenge through others
questions.correctAnswer: Harboring hatred can lead to further division and harm
questions.explanation: Absalom hated Amnon for forcing Tamar (2 Samuel 13:22) and later plotted revenge (13:28-29), which caused family strife. Forgiveness and reconciliation prevent such damage.

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 13 illustrate the importance of integrity and honesty within the family?
options: Deception and manipulation lead to destruction and broken relationships
Keeping secrets is necessary to protect family honor
Ignoring problems will make them disappear
Lying is acceptable if it benefits oneself
questions.correctAnswer: Deception and manipulation lead to destruction and broken relationships
questions.explanation: Amnon deceived his father and Tamar through feigned illness and manipulation (2 Samuel 13:5-10), resulting in harm and division in the family.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and dependence on God can be drawn from King David's reaction to his sons' conflict?
options: David mourned and sought God's help but was slow to act decisively
David immediately punished Amnon without sorrow
David ignored the situation to avoid conflict
David sided with Amnon without hearing Tamar
questions.correctAnswer: David mourned and sought God's help but was slow to act decisively
questions.explanation: David was very wroth and mourned (2 Samuel 13:21, 31), showing sorrow and dependence, but his delayed response allowed further problems.

questions.question: How does this chapter teach about the consequences of unchecked lust and lack of self-control?
options: Lust led Amnon to sin, hate, and ultimately his death
Lust has no serious consequences if kept private
Self-control is unnecessary in close family relationships
Sin can be excused if it arises from strong feelings
questions.correctAnswer: Lust led Amnon to sin, hate, and ultimately his death
questions.explanation: Amnon's uncontrolled lust caused him to rape Tamar (2 Samuel 13:14), hate her (13:15), and led to Absalom killing him (13:28-29).

questions.question: What does 2 Samuel 13 teach about the role of wise counsel in overcoming personal struggles?
options: Jonadab's counsel led Amnon to sin, showing the need for godly wisdom
Any counsel is helpful regardless of source
Friends should always support desires without question
Counsel is unnecessary if feelings are strong
questions.correctAnswer: Jonadab's counsel led Amnon to sin, showing the need for godly wisdom
questions.explanation: Jonadab, a subtle man, advised Amnon to feign sickness to get Tamar alone (2 Samuel 13:3-5), illustrating how bad counsel can lead to sin.

questions.question: A Christian parent wants to teach their child about purity and respect in relationships. What lesson from 2 Samuel 13 supports this?
options: Tamar's refusal shows the importance of respecting God's commands about purity
It is acceptable to force someone if you love them
Ignoring purity leads to peace
Family bonds override moral boundaries
questions.correctAnswer: Tamar's refusal shows the importance of respecting God's commands about purity
questions.explanation: Tamar repeatedly pleaded with Amnon not to force her, citing what is right in Israel (2 Samuel 13:11-14), emphasizing the value of purity and respect.

questions.question: True or False: Absalom immediately told King David about Amnon's wrongdoing against Tamar.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Absalom neither spoke good nor bad to Amnon for two years and did not inform David directly (2 Samuel 13:22, 23).

questions.question: True or False: After killing Amnon, Absalom fled and stayed in Geshur for three years.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Absalom fled to Geshur and was there three years after killing Amnon (2 Samuel 13:37-38).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: After being forced by Amnon, Tamar put ashes on her head, rent her ________, and cried bitterly.
options: garment of divers colours
hair
shoes
robe of mourning
questions.correctAnswer: garment of divers colours
questions.explanation: Tamar put ashes on her head and rent the garment of divers colours she wore, symbolizing her mourning and disgrace (2 Samuel 13:18, 19).

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 13 teach about the importance of protecting and caring for family members?
options: Absalom cared for Tamar by avenging her wrong, showing protective love
Family should stay uninvolved in each other's problems
Violence is the best way to solve family issues
Ignoring abuse is a form of love
questions.correctAnswer: Absalom cared for Tamar by avenging her wrong, showing protective love
questions.explanation: Absalom hated Amnon for hurting Tamar and planned to kill him to defend his sister’s honor (2 Samuel 13:22, 28-29), illustrating protective family love.

questions.question: What does the chapter suggest about the consequences of failing to discipline sin within the family?
options: Unaddressed sin leads to bitterness, revenge, and family breakdown
Ignoring sin keeps peace in the family
Sin will resolve itself without intervention
Discipline causes more harm than good
questions.correctAnswer: Unaddressed sin leads to bitterness, revenge, and family breakdown
questions.explanation: David’s failure to act decisively after Amnon's sin resulted in Absalom’s hatred and murder of Amnon, fracturing the family (2 Samuel 13:21, 22, 28-29).

questions.question: What lesson about humility and contentment can be learned from David's mourning over Amnon and Absalom?
options: David’s sorrow shows a father's humble acceptance of God’s sovereignty
David blamed others and refused to mourn
David acted with pride and sought revenge
David was indifferent to his sons’ conflict
questions.correctAnswer: David’s sorrow shows a father's humble acceptance of God’s sovereignty
questions.explanation: David mourned deeply yet showed no anger toward God or others, reflecting humility and trust despite tragedy (2 Samuel 13:31, 37-39).

questions.question: How does 2 Samuel 13 guide believers in responding to family injustice and suffering?
options: Seek justice with courage but avoid sinful revenge
Ignore injustice to keep peace
Respond with personal vengeance
Cover up the wrongdoing
questions.correctAnswer: Seek justice with courage but avoid sinful revenge
questions.explanation: Absalom sought justice for Tamar but used sinful violence (2 Samuel 13:28-29), showing believers should pursue justice but within God’s righteousness.

questions.question: What does the chapter teach about the role of prayer and intercession in family crises?
options: David’s mourning and seeking news demonstrate the need for prayerful concern
Prayer is unnecessary during family crises
One should act without seeking God’s guidance
Ignore problems and hope they resolve
questions.correctAnswer: David’s mourning and seeking news demonstrate the need for prayerful concern
questions.explanation: David’s reaction to the news, his mourning, and his longing for Absalom (2 Samuel 13:21, 31, 39) show the importance of prayer and seeking God in trials.

hard.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Samuel Chapter 13.

questions.question: What literary device is seen in the contrast between Amnon's initial love and subsequent hatred for Tamar in 2 Samuel 13?
options: Irony
Chiasm
Foreshadowing
Parallelism
questions.correctAnswer: Irony
questions.explanation: Amnon’s love turning into hatred after forcing Tamar demonstrates irony, as seen in 2 Samuel 13:15 where his hatred surpasses his initial love.

questions.question: In 2 Samuel 13, what role does Jonadab play in the narrative involving Amnon and Tamar?
options: He advises Amnon to feign illness to lure Tamar
He protects Tamar from Amnon
He informs King David of Amnon's sickness
He counsels Absalom to kill Amnon
questions.correctAnswer: He advises Amnon to feign illness to lure Tamar
questions.explanation: Jonadab, described as a 'very subtil man' (2 Samuel 13:3), advises Amnon to pretend to be sick to bring Tamar to him (2 Samuel 13:5).

questions.question: How is the cultural significance of Tamar’s garment illustrated in 2 Samuel 13?
options: It signifies her status as a virgin daughter of the king
It represents her marriage status
It is a symbol of mourning
It marks her as a priestess
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies her status as a virgin daughter of the king
questions.explanation: Tamar’s garment of divers colours was typical apparel for virgin daughters of the king, indicating her royal and virgin status (2 Samuel 13:18).

questions.question: Which theme in 2 Samuel 13 is foreshadowed by the conflict between Amnon and Absalom?
options: Familial strife and eventual rebellion against King David
Divine punishment for David's sins
Restoration of the Davidic kingdom
Peace between brothers
questions.correctAnswer: Familial strife and eventual rebellion against King David
questions.explanation: The hatred Absalom holds for Amnon and subsequent killing foreshadows the later rebellion of Absalom against David (2 Samuel 13:22, 28-29).

questions.question: What is the significance of Absalom hosting sheepshearers in Baalhazor in 2 Samuel 13?
options: It serves as a pretext to gather the king's sons and execute his plan against Amnon
It is a religious festival honoring God
It is a diplomatic event with neighboring tribes
It is a celebration of Amnon’s recovery
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as a pretext to gather the king's sons and execute his plan against Amnon
questions.explanation: Absalom uses the sheepshearers event to invite all the king’s sons and orchestrate the killing of Amnon (2 Samuel 13:23-29).

questions.question: True or False: King David immediately punished Amnon after hearing of his assault on Tamar.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Although David was very angry (2 Samuel 13:21), the text does not record any immediate punishment of Amnon by the king.

questions.question: What is the Hebrew meaning and significance of the name 'Jonadab,' and how does it reflect his character in 2 Samuel 13?
options: Jonadab means 'Yahweh is noble,' but he acts subtil and crafty
Jonadab means 'Gift of God,' reflecting his helpfulness
Jonadab means 'Faithful servant,' showing his loyalty
Jonadab means 'Peaceful one,' indicating his pacifism
questions.correctAnswer: Jonadab means 'Yahweh is noble,' but he acts subtil and crafty
questions.explanation: Jonadab's name implies nobility but contrasts with his cunning role in advising Amnon’s deceit (2 Samuel 13:3), highlighting the irony in his character.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage reflects on the theme of sexual sin and its consequences, as illustrated in 2 Samuel 13?
options: 2 Timothy 2:22
Romans 8:1
John 3:16
Hebrews 11:1
questions.correctAnswer: 2 Timothy 2:22
questions.explanation: 2 Timothy 2:22 advises fleeing youthful lusts, paralleling the consequences of Amnon's lust and sin in 2 Samuel 13.

questions.question: How does the episode of Tamar’s assault relate to the broader Deuteronomic law about sexual ethics?
options: It violates the law forbidding sexual relations with close relatives
It follows the law of levirate marriage
It exemplifies the law of restitution for rape
It is unrelated to Deuteronomic law
questions.correctAnswer: It violates the law forbidding sexual relations with close relatives
questions.explanation: Amnon's act is a violation of sexual ethics laws in Deuteronomy forbidding incestuous relations (Deuteronomy 27:20), as Tamar was his half-sister (2 Samuel 13:1-14).

questions.question: What is the historical and cultural significance of Absalom fleeing to Geshur after killing Amnon?
options: Geshur was a neighboring kingdom where Absalom’s maternal grandfather was king, providing refuge
Geshur was a distant enemy kingdom, making refuge unlikely
Geshur was part of David’s kingdom, signifying political asylum
Geshur was a desert region with no political ties
questions.correctAnswer: Geshur was a neighboring kingdom where Absalom’s maternal grandfather was king, providing refuge
questions.explanation: Absalom fled to Geshur, ruled by his maternal grandfather Talmai, providing political and familial refuge (2 Samuel 13:37-38).

questions.question: Which literary parallel can be drawn between Tamar’s lament in 2 Samuel 13:19 and other biblical expressions of mourning?
options: Tamar’s ashes and rent garment parallel Job’s expression of grief
Tamar’s lament is unique with no biblical parallels
Tamar’s lament parallels David’s mourning for Saul
Tamar’s lament is like Jonah’s prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Tamar’s ashes and rent garment parallel Job’s expression of grief
questions.explanation: Tamar putting ashes on her head and tearing her garment echoes Job’s and other biblical lament customs expressing deep sorrow (2 Samuel 13:19; Job 2:12).

questions.question: How does the narrative in 2 Samuel 13 illustrate the theme of justice and retribution in ancient Israelite society?
options: Absalom’s killing of Amnon is portrayed as retributive justice for Tamar’s violation
David immediately enforces legal justice by punishing Amnon
The narrative shows forgiveness and reconciliation between brothers
The law is shown to be ineffective in this story
questions.correctAnswer: Absalom’s killing of Amnon is portrayed as retributive justice for Tamar’s violation
questions.explanation: Absalom’s murder of Amnon is presented as an act of vengeance for his sister Tamar’s rape, reflecting customs of familial justice (2 Samuel 13:22, 28-29).

questions.question: What authorial intent might underlie the detailed description of Amnon’s deception and assault in 2 Samuel 13?
options: To warn against the abuse of power and the consequences of sin within the royal family
To glorify David’s family
To provide a mere historical record without moral commentary
To show political alliances among tribes
questions.correctAnswer: To warn against the abuse of power and the consequences of sin within the royal family
questions.explanation: The detailed narrative highlights the tragic consequences of Amnon’s abuse of royal privilege and sin, warning the audience about moral failure (2 Samuel 13:1-14).

questions.question: In what way does the episode involving Amnon and Tamar contribute to the development of the theme of dynastic conflict in the Books of Samuel?
options: It sets the stage for Absalom’s rebellion and challenges to David’s kingship
It shows the unity and strength of David’s family
It resolves the succession issues peacefully
It focuses solely on personal tragedy without political implications
questions.correctAnswer: It sets the stage for Absalom’s rebellion and challenges to David’s kingship
questions.explanation: The family strife caused by this incident escalates into Absalom’s rebellion, a key dynastic conflict in Samuel (2 Samuel 13:22, 37-38).

questions.question: Which thematic element in 2 Samuel 13 is reflected in the New Testament teaching about familial relationships and repentance?
options: The necessity of repentance and reconciliation despite family sin
The acceptance of family violence as divine will
The avoidance of family conflicts by ignoring them
The endorsement of revenge as righteous
questions.correctAnswer: The necessity of repentance and reconciliation despite family sin
questions.explanation: Though 2 Samuel 13 lacks explicit reconciliation, the New Testament (e.g., Matthew 5:23-24) emphasizes repentance and reconciliation, contrasting the tragic unresolved conflict here.

theological.title: 2 Samuel Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Samuel Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does the story of Amnon and Tamar in 2 Samuel 13 reveal about the nature of human sin and its effects on relationships?
options: Sin distorts love and leads to destruction of relationships
Sin is easily forgiven without consequences
Sin only affects the individual committing it
Sin is only a matter of external actions, not internal desires
questions.correctAnswer: Sin distorts love and leads to destruction of relationships
questions.explanation: 2 Samuel 13:1-15 shows how Amnon's sinful desire led him to violate Tamar, destroying their relationship and causing hatred. This aligns with biblical teaching that sin corrupts human hearts and relationships (James 1:14-15, Romans 3:23, Genesis 4:7, Proverbs 6:32).

questions.question: How does Absalom’s reaction to Tamar’s violation illustrate the biblical concept of justice and vengeance?
options: He takes personal vengeance by orchestrating Amnon's death
He immediately forgives Amnon and seeks peace
He ignores the offense and forgets about it
He appeals to the king for legal justice only
questions.correctAnswer: He takes personal vengeance by orchestrating Amnon's death
questions.explanation: Absalom’s response in 2 Samuel 13:23-29 shows personal vengeance rather than trusting God’s justice, reflecting the tension between divine justice (Romans 12:19) and human retribution (Proverbs 20:22). This illustrates the biblical warning against taking revenge into one’s own hands.

questions.question: What does King David’s response to the events in his household teach about the challenges of leadership and sin within a godly family?
options: Leaders can be deeply affected and grieved by sin in their own families
Leaders are always able to immediately resolve sin issues
Sin in the family has no impact on leadership
Leaders should ignore family sin to focus on the nation
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders can be deeply affected and grieved by sin in their own families
questions.explanation: David’s mourning and tearing his clothes (2 Samuel 13:21, 31) show the profound grief sin causes even in godly leaders. This aligns with biblical examples of leaders burdened by family sin (Genesis 37:34-35, 2 Samuel 12:13-14, Psalm 51:1-4).

questions.question: In what way does Jonadab’s advice to Amnon reveal the presence of deceit and manipulation in human sinfulness?
options: It shows how cunning planning can facilitate sinful desires
It encourages honesty and repentance
It promotes spiritual wisdom for good
It rebukes Amnon's intentions
questions.correctAnswer: It shows how cunning planning can facilitate sinful desires
questions.explanation: Jonadab’s subtle and crafty advice to feign illness to deceive Tamar (2 Samuel 13:3-6) demonstrates human sinfulness involving deceit, consistent with biblical warnings about subtlety in sin (Genesis 3:1, Jeremiah 17:9, Proverbs 12:20).

questions.question: What theological truth about God’s holiness and human sinfulness is highlighted by Tamar’s refusal to submit to Amnon’s proposal?
options: God’s law forbids sexual sin and calls for purity
God ignores sins committed by relatives
Sinful desires are acceptable if one loves the person
Human laws are more important than divine laws
questions.correctAnswer: God’s law forbids sexual sin and calls for purity
questions.explanation: Tamar’s protest (2 Samuel 13:12-13) reflects the biblical injunctions against incest and sexual immorality (Leviticus 18:6-18, 1 Corinthians 6:18, Hebrews 13:4), highlighting God’s call for holiness and purity.

questions.question: How does the episode of Absalom killing Amnon contribute to the biblical understanding of the consequences of unchecked sin?
options: Unaddressed sin leads to escalating violence and familial division
Sin can be contained without further consequences
Divine forgiveness automatically removes all consequences
Sin mainly affects only those who commit it
questions.correctAnswer: Unaddressed sin leads to escalating violence and familial division
questions.explanation: The murder of Amnon by Absalom (2 Samuel 13:28-29) shows how unresolved sin produces further sin and division, consistent with biblical teaching on the destructive ripple effects of sin (Genesis 4:8-12, Matthew 18:15-17, Galatians 6:7-8).

questions.question: Which attribute of God is implicitly challenged by the injustice and violence in this chapter, and how is this tension addressed in Scripture?
options: God’s justice; He will ultimately right all wrongs
God’s omnipresence; He is absent in times of trouble
God’s mercy; He ignores sin
God’s sovereignty; He has no control over evil
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice; He will ultimately right all wrongs
questions.explanation: The injustice in 2 Samuel 13 challenges God’s justice, but Scripture affirms that God is just and will ultimately judge sin righteously (Psalm 9:7-8, Romans 12:19, Revelation 20:12-13, Isaiah 61:8).

questions.question: What does David’s longing for Absalom after his exile reveal about the complexities of parental love and forgiveness in the presence of sin?
options: Parental love can coexist with sorrow and desire for reconciliation
Parents always reject sinful children permanently
Sin ends all familial love
Forgiveness is immediate and unconditional
questions.correctAnswer: Parental love can coexist with sorrow and desire for reconciliation
questions.explanation: David’s longing for Absalom (2 Samuel 13:38-39) demonstrates that parental love persists despite sin and estrangement, consistent with biblical themes of forgiveness, restoration, and mercy (Luke 15:11-32, Psalm 103:13, Ephesians 4:32).

questions.question: How does the episode of Tamar putting ashes on her head and tearing her garment symbolize biblical concepts of mourning and shame?
options: It represents deep grief and public expression of dishonor
It is a celebration of victory
It signals indifference to the situation
It is an act of rebellion against God
questions.correctAnswer: It represents deep grief and public expression of dishonor
questions.explanation: Tamar’s actions (2 Samuel 13:19) are biblical symbols of mourning and shame, used throughout Scripture to express sorrow and loss of honor (Esther 4:1, Job 2:12, Jeremiah 6:26, Ezekiel 7:18).

questions.question: What does the role of Jonadab in this chapter teach about human complicity in sin and the responsibility to resist temptation?
options: Complicity enables sin and those who counsel sin share guilt
Advisors bear no responsibility for others’ sins
Friendship always leads to righteousness
Sinful plans are excusable if advised by close friends
questions.correctAnswer: Complicity enables sin and those who counsel sin share guilt
questions.explanation: Jonadab’s counsel (2 Samuel 13:3-5, 32-33) shows how enabling sin implicates others, consistent with biblical teaching that those who aid sin are accountable (Proverbs 1:10-16, Galatians 6:1-2, 1 Timothy 5:22).

questions.question: How does the narrative of Amnon and Tamar prefigure the New Testament teachings on sexual sin and repentance?
options: It highlights the destructive nature of sexual sin and the need for repentance
It condones sexual sin if done in secrecy
It presents sin as inconsequential in the kingdom of God
It teaches that repentance is unnecessary
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights the destructive nature of sexual sin and the need for repentance
questions.explanation: The chapter’s depiction of sexual sin (2 Samuel 13:14-15) prefigures New Testament calls to flee sexual immorality and repent (1 Corinthians 6:18-20, Hebrews 13:4, 2 Timothy 2:22).

questions.question: What does the failure of King David to immediately punish Amnon suggest about human limitations in administering justice, compared with divine justice?
options: Human justice is often imperfect and delayed, unlike God’s perfect justice
Human justice always perfectly reflects God’s judgment
Leaders are exempt from addressing sin
Sin has no real consequences in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Human justice is often imperfect and delayed, unlike God’s perfect justice
questions.explanation: David’s inaction (2 Samuel 13:21-22) shows human weaknesses in dispensing justice, contrasting with God’s perfect and timely judgment (Ecclesiastes 8:11, Romans 12:19, Psalm 7:11, Isaiah 30:18).

questions.question: How does the theme of broken family relationships in this chapter reflect the broader biblical narrative of sin’s impact on human community?
options: Sin causes alienation and division within families and communities
Sin strengthens family bonds
Sin has no effect on human relationships
Sin only affects strangers, not family
questions.correctAnswer: Sin causes alienation and division within families and communities
questions.explanation: The broken relationships in 2 Samuel 13 (Amnon, Tamar, Absalom) illustrate sin’s divisive impact, consistent with biblical teaching on sin causing estrangement and conflict (Genesis 3:16-17, 1 Corinthians 1:10, Ephesians 4:31-32).

questions.question: What Christological theme can be drawn from Tamar’s suffering and David’s grief in this chapter?
options: The innocent suffer and the righteous grieve, pointing to Christ’s atoning sacrifice
Suffering is always a sign of divine rejection
Grief is evidence of lack of faith
Christ’s work does not address human suffering
questions.correctAnswer: The innocent suffer and the righteous grieve, pointing to Christ’s atoning sacrifice
questions.explanation: Tamar’s victimization and David’s mourning (2 Samuel 13:19, 31) foreshadow the innocent suffering of Christ and the grief of God over sin, fulfilling Isaiah 53 and 1 Peter 2:21-24.

questions.question: How does the narrative illustrate the biblical principle that sin’s consequences often extend beyond the individual to affect entire families and nations?
options: Amnon’s sin leads to family strife, exile, and political instability
Sin only harms the sinner alone
Sin never affects relationships beyond immediate acts
Sin is only a private matter
questions.correctAnswer: Amnon’s sin leads to family strife, exile, and political instability
questions.explanation: The chapter shows how Amnon’s sin results in Absalom’s murder of him and his own exile (2 Samuel 13:28-38), evidencing sin’s widespread impact consistent with biblical teaching (Exodus 20:5, Numbers 14:18, Hosea 4:6).

questions.question: What does the story reveal about the importance of God’s law in maintaining social and moral order?
options: God’s law forbids folly like Amnon’s actions and protects human dignity
God’s law is optional and irrelevant
Moral order is maintained by human wisdom alone
Social order does not depend on obedience to God
questions.correctAnswer: God’s law forbids folly like Amnon’s actions and protects human dignity
questions.explanation: Tamar’s appeal to the law (2 Samuel 13:12) highlights the role of God’s commandments in restraining sin and preserving justice, consistent with biblical emphasis on law for holy living (Deuteronomy 6:24, Psalm 119:9, Romans 7:12).
